explanations.A: I think you've worked this out as if it were a fair die, which isn't the case here. Ask yourself what fraction of the time is a 6 rolled, then you can work out the best guess by finding this fraction of 1000.
explanations.B: Nineteen is the frequency of 6s recorded for 40 rolls of the die, so the fraction of 6s recorded is 19/40. This enables us to make a 'best guess' at the number if 1000 were to be rolled: 19/40 × 1000 = (19 × 1000) ÷ 40 = 475. Another way of looking at this is to say there are 1000 ÷ 40 = 25 times more rolls, so the best guess is that there will be 25 times more 6s = 25 × 19 = 475.
explanations.C: Nineteen would be the best guess if there were 40 rolls of the die. We need to scale this up for 1000 rolls. How many times more than 40 is this?
explanations.D: You've worked out how many times bigger 1000 is than 40, which is useful! What effect will this have on the best guess answer?

explanations.A: Twenty-seven would be the best guess if there were 80 rolls of the die. We need to scale this up for 400 rolls. How many times more than 80 is this?
explanations.B: You've worked out how many times bigger 400 is than 80, which is useful! What effect will this have on the best guess answer?
explanations.C: I think you've worked this out as if it were a fair die, which isn't the case here. Ask yourself what fraction of the time is a 6 rolled, then you can work out the best guess by finding this fraction of 400.
explanations.D: Twenty-seven is the frequency of 6s recorded for 80 rolls of the die, so the fraction is 27/80. This enables us to make a 'best guess' at the number if 400 were to be rolled: 27/80 × 400 = (27 × 400) ÷ 80 = 135. Another way of looking at this is to say there are 400 ÷ 80 = 5 times more rolls, so the best guess is that there will be 55 times more 6s = 5 × 27 = 135.
